metadata.case_name: Property Owner v. Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation

facts.text: Appellant is the owner of an immovable property situate within the limits of the respondent-Corporation.

Until March 31, 1961, two kinds of taxes were levied: 1) general tax by Corporation under Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949; 2) urban immovable property tax (U.I.P. tax) under Bombay Finance Act, 1932 by State Government, collected by Corporation.
In 1960, at request of Corporation, arrangement arrived between Government and Corporation: Government agreed not to levy U.I.P. tax if Corporation increased property tax rate.
In January 1961, Corporation passed resolution increasing rate of property tax with effect from April 1, 1961 under S.127 of the Act.
In pursuance of resolution, Corporation served bills and demand notices on appellant and other rate payers for assessment year 1962-63.
Appellant and other rate payers filed seventy Special Civil Applications in Gujarat High Court challenging validity of assessment, including SCA No. 877 of 1962 by appellant.

Gujarat High Court by judgment dated May 5, 1966 disposed of 52 writ petitions rejecting contentions; later disposed of remaining 18 including appellant's, basing on earlier judgment, and dismissed all.

High Court conclusions: Corporation need not maintain separate assessment-book for each ward; authentication under r.19 not mandatory; liability arises on entry under r.9(e); S.129(c) with ss.99,127 no excessive delegation; not violative of Arts.19(1)(f),31,14.

Each year Commissioner prepared or continued assessment-book under Taxation Rules; went through procedure for authentication under r.19; after authentication and certificate under r.9(e) that no valid objection received, Corporation issued bills.
Commissioner maintained one assessment-book covering all wards, not separate ward assessment-books.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate challenging High Court judgments.
Appellant gave up third contention regarding enhanced rate not applicable to property not previously subject to U.I.P. tax.
Gujarat State Legislature by Act 8 of 1968 amended cl.(c) of S.129 inserting maximum rate of 30%, relevant only for years prior to amendment.

legal_issues.text: Whether while making the assessment the procedure contemplated by ss.127, 129(c) of the Act and rr.9 to 20 of the Taxation Rules was not complied with inasmuch as no ward assessment-books were maintained, and consequently, the entries therein were not authenticated as required by r.19.
Whether S.129 suffers from the vice of excessive delegation of legislative power as the Act fails to provide either the maximum rate leviable by the Corporation or the guidelines for levying the tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: Corporation had no authority to amend rates with object of including U.I.P. tax in general tax.
Bills and notices illegal as assessment-book not in accordance with rules and not authenticated by Commissioner.
Ss.99,123,129(c) unconstitutional for excessive delegation as no maximum rate fixed.
No valid assessment-book as rules require ward assessment-books for each ward, not one for whole city; hence breach of procedure.
S.129(c) excessive delegation: no maximum rate or guidelines; allows arbitrary levy for discretionary functions under S.66.

respondent_arguments.text: One assessment-book covering all wards legally maintainable; authentication under r.19 not mandatory.
Liability to pay tax arises on entry under r.9(e); authentication is rule of evidence, not condition for liability.
S.129(c) read with ss.99,127 no excessive delegation; policy and principles in Act; controls via budget, municipal fund, councillors.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ss.82,86,88,89,95-100; precedential support from Liberty Cinema

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held no need for separate ward books; r.10 discretionary; authentication r.19 not mandatory for liability which arises on r.9(e) entry; applies to single book too via inadvertent language retention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature deliberately departed from Bombay Act 1888 S.157 giving option in r.10; r.19 makes entries conclusive evidence for billing, applies to single book; rights under rr.13,15 vital, must apply regardless.

court_reasoning.text: No excessive delegation in S.129(c): taxes only for Act purposes; controls via municipal fund ss.82-89, budget ss.95-100, elected councillors, State oversight ss.454-457; absence of max rate not fatal per precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delegation to local body valid if guided by Act scheme; needs variable per city; State can amend as done in 1968.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished earlier HC decision under Boroughs Act; r.9(e) with r.30 fixes liability accrual.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Different scheme in Boroughs Act lacking r.9(e).

holdings.text: Assessment-book valid even if single for all wards; procedure complied with; authentication under r.19 applies and entries conclusive.
S.129(c) not excessive delegation; sufficient guidance in Act provisions and scheme for local self-government.

precedents_cited.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema
precedents_cited.relevance: Fixation of tax rate not essential legislative function; can be delegated if guidance; needs of delegate provide guidance; no max rate needed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Theatres Ltd. v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Poona
precedents_cited.relevance: Policy in 'for purposes of this Act'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation for tax details valid if legislature retains control.
Liberty Cinema confined to municipal acts; no guidance in sales tax statute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Mills
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation to elected local body valid; factors like purposes, budget, courts provide guidance even without max rate for optional functions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad v. Zaveri Keshavlal
precedents_cited.relevance: Under different Boroughs Act scheme; liability after authentication there.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949 (LIX of 1949)
sections: Taxation Rules Ch.VIII Sch.A rr.9-21, r.30
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs levy, assessment, rates of property tax; rules for assessment-book; delegation upheld as guided.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Finance Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Urban immovable property tax, discontinued per arrangement.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation by delegation or procedure; tax not confiscatory.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Act 8 of 1968
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted max rate 30% post relevant years.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, 1888
statutes_cited.relevance: Source of rules; deliberate departure in r.10.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Gujarat High Court judgments; held assessment procedure valid with single assessment-book and no excessive delegation in S.129(c); bills and demand notices valid.

key_quotes.text: "fixation of the rate was not an essential legislative function and could be delegated, and that the provisions in the Act, which limited the power to levy taxes to the extent of the statutory needs of the Corporation, furnished sufficient control and guidance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Relied on Liberty Cinema to uphold delegation.

key_quotes.text: "Provision for such maximum only sets out a limit of the rate to be imposed and a limit is only a limit and not a guidance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why absence of max rate not fatal.

key_quotes.text: "the ultimate control, both for raising the taxes and incurring expenditure, lies with the councillors chosen by and responsible to the people."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to validity of delegation to elected body.

key_quotes.text: "it was through inadvertence that the old language used in ss.157 to 168 of the Bombay Corporation Act was allowed to be retained without carrying out the change of language necessitated as a result of r.10."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves interpretation of 'ward assessment-book' in rules.
